message: Life settles you down.
All that peace and love will make you tense.
Boy giving a close-up inspection of an exhibit at Greenpoint's "Bring the Light" exhibition.
Furfect.
La Puerta.
Occupy Wall Street : gettin' weird.
She seemed worthy of a close-up.

"I used to work on Wall Street."
"Before or after the face tats?"
Love the unity here between art, artist, environment.
I loved all her grays.

I was just recycling some memory cards and I came across the first "street portrait" that I ever took.  This was number one of several thousand.  I remember being really nervous that I'd get "caught."
Somehow a Wall Street banker managed to squeeze past the pitchfork perimeter.  He headed straight for the beating heart of the protest -- the Dorito supply.

I've been thinking about "letting go" of HONY a little to bring in some fresh talent/content.  But I was worried about keeping the quality and content consistent.  Recently I discovered a filmmaker named Adele Pham-- and I think her skills really mesh well with the site.  Thinking about bringing her on board to handle video.

"Fairy tales can come true, it can happen to you
If you're young at heart
For it's hard, you will find, to be narrow of mind
If you're young at heart"
An interesting Spanish woman sitting on the steps of St. John's Cathedral last evening.
The Reading Lesson
Central Park: a great place to take your girl.
Central Park Terrorsel.

Some come to Occupy Wall Street for social justice.
Others come for world peace.
Still others, for epic squirrel portraits.

This Village Elder was dispensing the wisdom of the Universe.  I waited in line for my turn.  But the session before me took twenty minutes-- so I decided that enlightenment took entirely too long and continued hunting for squirrel portraits.  Squirtraits.
Home is wherever I'm with you.

Occupy Wall Street's biggest weakness is that it's very diffuse, unfocused, and brings together a myriad of world views.  It lacks a clear message.  But this "big tent" philosophy, while a tactical weakness, is a poetic strength.
CAPTION CONTEST: Submit a caption.  Winner will go on the main site tomorrow.  If you can't think of one, "like" your favorite.
Street Ball
NA
NA

It's not hard to be ambiguous.  
But it's hard to be comfortably ambiguous.
Suddenly the street sermon uncomfortably shifts to the subject of The White Man.
Neighborhood beautification begins in the mirror.
NA

Recently classified as Extinct, the slow-moving Metallicus Eccentricus was recently seen crossing 5th Ave. This creature is highly endangered because it is completely blind and feeds only on attention.

Hands down the most adorable solution to the economic crisis:
Tax the Princesses

Wendell is a clothing designer with a long history of crack addiction.  He still puts together clothes with materials he finds in the trash.  He's often very combative and will never let me take a decent portrait.  But today he was strangely serene.
Every movement has its philosophers.

Some forward-looking fashion on the high line yesterday.
A provoking mix of The Jetsons and Sarah Palin's Alaska.
The world is full of people standing in perfect places.
NA
If grandma ain't happy, ain't nobody happy.
Cowboys and Indians
Sometimes the best background is, well, the ground.
The good people at Scoutmob NYC just did a feature with a few of my OWS photos.

This may be the first photo I've ever posted that I didn't take.  It's an AP Photo.  Regardless of your views on OWS, it's a pretty iconic representation of what's going on.  I really sympathize with both people in this picture. The kid, exercising his rights. The cop, just doing his job.
China's covert propaganda campaign is not going as well as hoped.
Every once in awhile I'll do a portrait for friends.  Which is fun because they tend to be so much more pliable than strangers.  :)

If these two don't make you want to group hug,
you just don't like group hugs.
Brooklyn by way of Ethiopia.
"When you leave New York, you are astonished at how clean the rest of the world is. Clean is not enough."  -Fran Lebowitz
Found this young woman at the Creator's Project in Brooklyn last night.  Loved how she was coordinating with the brick wall behind her, and even the water stains on the ground.
If this picture looks like a giant robot man walking in the middle of the street, it's because there was a giant robot man walking in the middle of the street.
Went to Comic Con yesterday.  It's a good thing to see, once.

"When I was living in New York and didn't have a penny to my name, I would walk around the streets and occasionally I would see an alcove or something. And I'd think, that'll be good, that'll be a good spot for me when I'm homeless."  -Larry David
Here's a Comic Con participant that I thought deserved a split-screen.
Met Sam in Union Square Park tonight.  He's 19.  He loves dance, studies neuroscience, and wants to be a monk.  He can also do awesome things with his glass orb.

If you can't own a house in NYC,
you can at least own the sidewalk.
"No urban night is like the New York night... Squares after squares of flame, set up and cut into the aether. Here is our poetry, for we have pulled down the stars to our will."  -Ezra Pound
Nothing completes a wall of graffiti like a good sweater vest.

Facebook has recently allowed me to track who shares photos.  I'm going to send an inscribed 4x6 print to anyone who shares 15 or more photos before the end of the year.  You can share new or old photos.  There are 3,000 to choose from.  You guys are the reason HONY is growing so fast.  Thanks for spreading the word!
NA
A little chicken soup from the Midwest on a rainy Wednesday in the City:
Can't leave your car for a minute in this city.

His mom was screaming: "Put it down!"
I was screaming: "Hold it up!"
There's no such thing as a relaxing ride home.

This poster hangs in the window of a Laundromat near my apartment.
It is not suggestive of a pleasant laundry experience.
NA

"New York still has so much pizzazz, because people make it new every day. Like all cities, it’s self-organizing. People looking for a date on Third Avenue make it into a place full of hope and expectation, and this has nothing to do with architecture. Those are the emotions that draw us to cities, and they depend on things being a bit messy. The most perfectly designed place can’t compete." -Jane Jacobs
The squeaky wheel gets the grease.
Young Dracula.

My relationship with Wendell has evolved considerably.
He actually stops screaming and holds still for me now.
Gray is a good color.
Street Fight in Chinatown: Can you find both Corona bottles?
"New York is the meeting place of the peoples, the only city where you can hardly find a typical American." -Dhuja Barnes

"You look good."
"I look good cause I am good."

"Do you mind if I take your photo?"
"We have to get some coffee."
"I'll wait."

It's very clear when Chinatown changes into Little Italy.  
The signs change from Chinese to Italian,
and suddenly everyone loves to be photographed.
NA
Just when you thought your day couldn't get any more adorable...
Somebody told on our topless photo yesterday and Facebook removed the content, accompanied by a stern warning.  I bet it was those bastards over at Humans of New Jersey.

Apparently Facebook won't let you show a woman's breasts.
Unless they were painted by a man.
Seen in Clinton Hill
There's so many uncontrollable variables in street photography.  Sometimes photos just happen-- so I feel like I can say "Wow, that's beautiful," without feeling like I'm patting myself on the back.
La petite danseuse.
Gun control laws are clearly not working.
NA
That's nothing, you should have seen the other guy.
Goodnight, everyone.

Raphaelle is from Paris.  Next spring she is getting her PHD in Philosophy from NYU.  Her specific interest is crime, and the difference between revenge and punishment.  But seriously-- intelligence is so attractive.
Seventy-three years old, going on eighteen.
If you're not willing to step in front of a moving Mack truck for a good street portrait, the fire is gone.
"I don't believe in luck.  I only believe in work." -Pablo Picasso
Sometimes I get a little overexcited after a great portrait, and force an awkward hug on the subject.  I realize pretty soon that I'm hugging a non-hugger.  But it's too late.
Twins

"When you post my picture, can you write sammy-slash- machine?"
"You got it."

Sammy/Machine
Click here: http://bit.ly/u0Sr9C

Some learn to ride.
Some were born to ride.
How beautiful are these two?
Me and Susie take our first annual autumn portrait.
The best part of my job is being able to bring joy to the faces of children.
The Red Queen
Doorways make such nice frames.
NA
I'm a seeker of everyday heroics.
Seen in Washington Square Park
NA

A girl dangling off the edge of the GW bridge.  Several cop cars showed up a few minutes later after several 911 calls.  Asked what she was doing, she said: "Enjoying life."  Strangely poetic that one person's enjoyment of life can appear to so many as a desire for death.
If this photo had audio, you would hear me saying: "Oh. My. God."
This place gets so dead at night.
A terrifying spawn of Hell.
NA
Every time you think you've got the best ___________ in New York, something better comes around the corner.
NA
Diamonds on the inside

"Why are you photographing homeless people?"
"I'm not.  I'm photographing friendship."
NA
Can't tell you how many battles I've waged with elegant older women for permission to take their photograph.  I usually prevail, though this lady won the right to retain her grandson's soccer ball.
Boy do I have a story coming up for you guys...

We passed 4,000 fans this evening.  Appropriate timing, because one year ago today I took a one-way flight to New York.  I may be a small part of your day, but you guys are the whole part of my day.  Thank you.  Here's the first photo I took in my new hometown:  November 2nd, 2010.
These two were walking past the Brooklyn Museum last night.
NA
NA
NA
It's always nice when a musician shares his instrument along with his music.  (And if you haven't read the Flashing Bill Cosby story from yesterday-- you're the only one.  5,000 views in 10 hours)
I'm just so proud to be contributing substantive topics to the public discourse.
A very nice write-up from Kuriositas about HONY.  Which is an honor- cause that's a really cool site!
I'm going to go out on a limb and say that this man has never participated in a drum circle.
Dogs don't judge you.
Occupy Wall Street continues to splinter.
Getting tender scenes in rough neighborhoods means looking really tough, but acting really soft.

I never know how people will respond to a portrait request.
There are "perfect" people who get very offended.
And there are imperfect people who feel quite honored.  
One's self-image comes from a deeper source than outward appearance.

Though the winners have already finished,
the marathon's real heroes are just warming up.
http://www.humansofnewyork.com/2011/11/07/real-heroes-of-the-new-york-city-marathon/
The best way you can possibly spend three minutes on a Monday morning: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nifq3Ke2Q30

There's only one way to start the week off right:
And that's similar-looking little people in matching heart jackets.

The first time I saw this man was in the subway.  He walked into my subway car and shouted: "ATTENTION EVERYONE."  He was selling vials of scented oil, which were strapped to his chest like machine gun cartridges.  Ironically, the next time I saw him was at a Rally Against Islamophobia.

My friend Sam has always thought that this was my best portrait,
and wants to know why I've never posted it.  So this is for him.

"Can I take your photo?"
"I don't think so."
"But you look like Fall."

A lot of times I'll take a walk just for enjoyment.  I plan on relaxing and not looking for photos.    But at the last minute I grab my camera, "just in case I see something really, really good."  Ten minutes later I'm dashing through traffic to intercept someone on the opposing sidewalk.
Something's not right here.

Tonight at 7:00 ET, I am going to be the guest speaker at a "Webinar" run by Phototour DC.  I'll speak for 20 or 30 minutes about my approach to photography.  It's free to join, but I think they are almost filled up.  If you're interested, you can register at: https://www3.gotomeeting.com/register/358028950
One of the strange poeticisms of life is that sometimes it takes another person to make you realize you were lonely.
This creature tried to sneak by me when I was photographing the marathon.  Nice try creature.

Boy do I have a story/photo coming up for you guys.
(Oh yes, we did.)
http://www.humansofnewyork.com/2011/11/09/flashing-bill-clinton/
Underneath it all, it's about one thing.
This is fun: noticed thousands of people coming to HONY from twitter.  The source?  A Mexican billionaire.

For everyone who has a print coming: I'm sending them out tomorrow, thanks for your patience!  For everyone else, the rule is: Share 15 photos by the end of the year, and I will mail you an inscribed 4 x 6 print of your choice!  (Email me at bstantonphoto@gmail.com when you've finished)
Walking the Dog
...and don't you forget it.
Something tells me that this one's going to have an early curfew when she's a teenager.
Million Dollar Baby

After I took this photo, I showed it to him.
"Oh man," he said. "Nothing lasts forever."

"Can I take your photo?"
"I didn't hear a thing you just said."
I'll be honest-- for someone attempting to create a comprehensive photographic survey, I've been spending way too many beautiful days in Central Park.  But somehow I don't feel too guilty...
Fall Collection
We always hurt the things we love.
Get out and stretch.

"Why do you want to take my photo?"
"You have a great face."
"I look like God.  Don't I?"
Tip Toes
All Wrapped Up

I don't think I've ever made a person's day by taking their photo,
like I made this man's day by taking his photo.
He's going to be a player.

I realize there's been an overabundance of kids lately.
But, I mean, really, c'mon:
Sometimes they come preframed.
Party of Six
Silent Symphony
Generation Gap
Young Women, Old Leaves
King Midas
On a beautiful Fall day in Central Park, even the simplest acts have a gleam of romanticism.

Sent out about 50 signed prints yesterday morning.  If you don't get your's within a week, send me another email.  If you sent me an email in the last two or three days, your's will be in the next batch.  I've enjoyed reading all the notes, thank you so much.  Again, everyone who wants a print has until Dec. 31st to share 15 photos.  There was a much larger response than I anticipated but I've enjoyed doing this.  Here's the most popular request so far, hands-down:
I'm always looking for ways to get creative with symmetry.
A Muscovite at the Museum of Modern Art.
American Style

"I'm the Santa Claus at Rockefeller Center."
"How'd you get that gig?"
"My agent."
"Life is a sad song, but those are the most beautiful." -Sam Ward

This man was in no mood for a photo because his Cadillac had just broken down.

I want to alert all the ladies out there to Larry's updated relationship status.  Larry enjoys loitering, weed smoking, and meteorology.  He's spent a little time in prison, but who hasn't?
The best part about this portrait is that the girl, the dog, and the couch are all meeting each other for the first time.

Here's a cheery looking fellow to kickstart the week.
Check out the video in the comments section.
NA
If I'm not mistaken, somebody is wearing her sexy face.
I felt like an evangelical healer when I took this photo because when I asked for her portrait, she threw her cane in the bushes.
Even the hotdogs have PHDs in this job market.

You never need a couple's permission to take a photograph.
You need the woman's permission.
Completely Natural
I think my most common explanation has become:  "You have a great face."  Even if a person is eight feet tall and covered in body piercings, I'll say: "Can I take your photo?  You have a great face."

No matter how cold it gets, no matter how hard its raining, no matter how long it's been since you've found a good portrait-- you've just got to believe that this man is waiting around the next corner.
Passed 5,000 "likes" last night.  Took about 6 months to reach our first thousand-- but only  3 weeks to reach our last.  Seems like something's brewing... thanks everyone!
Gotta love these two.

In all cities, neighborhoods look different.
In the world's noisiest city, neighborhoods sound different.
I once asked God to make all karmic credits payable in photographs.
Happy Thanksgiving!
This rare bird seems to be attracted to parades, celebrations, and large crowds.
Take a Ride on the Wild Side
This photo is unedited.
Internal Dialogue: "Oh God look at that one."
Something about her was very arresting.
If you think HONY is a little heavy on the kids, I want to apologize in advance.  For the month of December.
NA
Urban Safari
I continue to be excited about my upcoming Kids Looking at Christmas collection, which I will be gathering over the next few weeks.
Forever Young
I know this is an obscure reference-- but ever since I read Just Kids, I've been projecting Patti and Robert onto certain young couples I see around New York.
More Kids Looking at Christmas

Jen Doll is an excellent writer who was the catalyst for some of the earliest articles about HONY.  This week she was given the cover of Village Voice for her article "How to Be a New Yorker."  Despite the gimmicky title-- it is nuanced, accurate, and inspiring.
Earth Tones
"I know this sounds bad-- but my Facebook Group is going to love your legs."
Actual tree huggers in Washington Square Park yesterday.
"Is there any way you can put those horns on your head?"

Three things that never get by me: 
twins, old couples in love, and face tattoos.
Touching Up
NA
Adventures of Robo Dog

"I need you to put your entire personality into this next shot."
"OK.  I'm ready."
Hell's Angels are making a comeback.
"I don't mind the trees, but they didn't have to take up all the benches.  People use these benches to eat their lunch!"

"Attention everyone-- I am not asking for money.  The girl that I love has dumped me.  And I have no idea what to do or how to get her back.  Any ideas would be appreciated."    [And Ladies: if your ex-boyfriend was screaming this on the subway, would you be more or less likely to take him back?]

*Hi Brandon,

This is the guy who had the girlfriend sandwich board sign in the subway.  As I said when you asked, you may use my photograph, but please do not misquote me.  This was my pitch:  "Goodmorning New York.  I'm sorry to bother you.  I'm not hungry.  I do not want food or money, I just need a little support.  I got dumped last week and I'm trying to give her space but I can't do nothing.  If you have any words of advice for me, a quote that resonates with you or a story about second chances, please raise your hand and I'll come to you.  I have sharpie markers and I'll stay as long as it takes."  You may choose to include the entire quote or parts of it, but you may not make up what I said and put it in quotes.  Otherwise kindly take my photo down from the website and facebook page.

Regards,

JG

Due to a less-than-overwhelming response to Larry's quest for a mate, he's decided to go with a new look.  So for all you ladies who like your men clean-shaven, Larry can be found on the Washington Square Park benches.  Monday-Sunday, 9 AM to 9 PM.  Serious inquiries only.
Somebody took this kid's lunch money one too many times.

This is weird, awesome, hilarious, and New Yorky.
"You're welcome" in advance.
Christmas-themed flashmob dance party in Chelsea on Friday.

Susie, trusted advisor and official Humans of New York mascot, sports a brand new hoodie from HONY fan LuAnne Holladay.  If anyone else wants to dress up Susie, knock yourself out and I'll publish the results.

Every once in awhile the Hunter College MFA program opens its studios to the public.  (So neanderthals like myself can glimpse fine art.)  Lina has only been painting for one year, but clearly has incredible talent.

I think I've done something astounding here.
I think I just photographed America.

"May I take your photo?"
"Are you sending me to HOLLYWOOD???"
".... yes."
"Send me to Hollywood!!!!"
Christmas in the Lower East Side Projects
Parks and Recreation

I have this sort of magical, instant rapport with the children.
The same kind that Godzilla has.
This year's work clothes, next year's Spring Collection.
NA

Another kid looking at Christmas.  (Also: I'm going to be couch hopping for a week or so here, so updates may be a little less frequent for a bit.  But that's how you gotta roll when you're taking pictures of people on the street.)
I'm always interested in the mannerisms, gestures, and attitudes that adolescents adopt in their attempts to leapfrog into adulthood.
In winter I lose my main demographic: "people hanging out."

Three reasons this is the world's greatest hat:
1) It says Stud
2) It's being worn by this guy
3) It says "Body Detergent,"  which I'm not even going to google.  I'd like it to remain a mystery.

"Let's move into better light."
"I can't."
"Why?"
"I broke down."

"So do you do a different color every day?"
"No, I used to go through different stages.  But then I found that I was happiest when I was green, so I've been green for 15 years."

BREAKING NEWS:
World's most hilarious tag discovered on hat at Union Square bodega.
"Hey!  You look like the gargoyle.  Hold still."
Olympic gold medalist Cullen Jones spoke to the swim team at my neighborhood YMCA.  I volunteered to photograph the event.  Of course I had to snatch a HONY pic from the bargain.

This groundbreaking piece of work is entitled: 
 "Man Carries Dog Like Loaf of Bread."  

It will be on display at the Guggenheim through February.
I've taken thousands of portraits.  And I've never encountered a genuine, open-mouthed pose such as this.  I feel blessed and humbled.

Doesn't get any weirder/better than this.  Some man has arranged three cats, two fake cats, two dogs, a fake dog, two fake birds, and a gerbil into a sort of holiday display on 6th Avenue.  I paid $1 to take a picture, but I sort of felt that I was supporting something bad.  Like a crack habit.
I'm pretty sure Albert Einstein was hunting for a place to piss.

Larry appears to have completely abandoned his search for love, focusing instead on decorating his bench for the upcoming holiday.  Recently his Christmas mood was soured when some bums ran off with his tree's only ornament.

“You get closer to God by loving.”
“OK, but how do you love?”
“You love by giving.”
This guy really knows how to make an exit.

"What are you guys camping out for?"
"Justin Beiber sneakers."
"When do they come out?"
"Saturday.  We've been here since yesterday."
"Oh my God.  Everyone in for a photo."
I gave it a pity dollar.

My creative process:
1) Holy shit, Christmas lights!
2) Holy shit, Robo Man!
I think I may begin incorporating a new class of photos: the refusals

Guys, when commenting on future photos, please assume that the person in the photo will also be reading the comments.  Had to take down a photo for the first time today.  It's OK to assume the person has a sense of humor.  Just don't be mean.
World's Greatest Husband discovered on Kingston Ave.
Apparently I'm the only one bothered by the man dipping his power saw into a pool of glass shards.
My biggest pet peeve is when I ask a woman for her photograph and the man answers.
"I'm just an old woman who needs to find a store but can't see the signs."

Tourists encounter a flock of pigeons in Washington Square Park.
Hilarity ensues.
So he's got pink gloves, watcha gonna do about it?
Landscape painting - Bear Grylls edition.
Happy Holidays!
He's lost all composure.

Just sent out another batch of signed prints to everyone who has shared 15 or more photos.  Thanks for the patience.  For the rest of you -- you still have until the end of the year to share 15 photos and you will receive a signed 4x6 print of your choice.  If you think you're finished, email me at bstantonphoto@gmail.com.  I doubt I will ever do something like this again because it's really pushed my organizational skills to the limit.  Thanks everyone!  :)

"You may have seen me on the Public Television show: Are You a Star or Are You Bizarre?"
"Were you a star or were you bizarre?"
"I was the judge."
If the woman in the background seems perplexed, it's because he just screamed "SMILE" in her face.  I don't know why.

Perhaps the gayest portrait I've ever taken.
And there have been some gay ones.

Found this heroic man outside a store in SoHo.  
He was perched like an ancient sea captain.  
"I'm just waiting on the women," he said.
In the city, you gotta hold on tight.

This is George.  He had his left leg "blown clean off" in Pearl Harbor.

"I think your eyes were closed in that one, George."
"No, I just have small eyes."
"Look at the picture.  They were definitely closed.
"Nope.  That's just how they look."

When I first started HONY, I had a lot of ordinary, everyday worker portraits.  
But then the demand for children, old ladies, and eccentrics just kept growing.  I guess you could say I kind of "sold out."
Try before you buy.
Happy Holidays!
"Let me see that pic---- ah shit, I look bad.  But you cool man.  You cool."

Yesterday HONY fan Miryam Segal helped embed me in the Chabad Jews' "Car Menorah" Parade.  I ended up packed in a tiny RV with these guys.  We drove all around Manhattan screaming "Happy Hanukkah" at strangers.  I'm pretty sure for an entire year I've avoided saying this, but I LOVE NEW YORK.

Reincarnation of Jimi Hendrix discovered on Fulton Street.
Graphic Designer.  Enjoys Yoga.

You better be a rock star if you dress like this.
Cause if you're an accountant, you're going to disappoint a lot of people.
Unless you're a rock star's accountant.
You don't need a deed to own the sidewalk.

At no time is the gentrification of Brooklyn more evident than Christmas--
when all the white kids go "home."

I took this woman's photo yesterday because she "looked like Christmas." 
Her name is Maia.  It must have been fate, because she told me about this: http://vimeo.com/31733784
It's my gift to all of you.  Merry Christmas, everyone.

"Do you mind if I take your photo?"
"You sure you want me?  He can do a handstand."
"Wait.  Who can do a handstand?"
"I'm Vixen."

Merry Christmas from Humans of New York!
Remember to count your blessings.

Merry Christmas from Humans of New York!
And again, remember to count your blessings.

"What are you doing?"
"Putting a rainbow on the Christmas Tree!"
"What does that symbolize?"
"Everything!"
Merry Christmas from Humans of New York!  (And Susie)

New York City provides a reason to be optimistic.
It shows that the world can live together in one place.

"Are you going to make fun of me?"
"Not at all.  I love your colors."
NA

Noticing three distinct characters converging on a single point, 
I prepared for a spectacular collision.

Why did I photograph this man? 
Look very closely.

Any artists out there?  This thought inspired me at an early age.
It's the ultimate "content-over-technique," "experience-over education" quote:

"In going where you have to go, and doing what you have to do, and seeing what you have to see, you dull and blunt the instrument you write with. But I would rather have it bent and dulled and know I had to put it on the grindstone again and hammer it into shape and put a whetstone to it, and know that I had something to write about, than to have it bright and shining and nothing to say, or smooth and well oiled in the closet, but unused." -Ernest Hemingway
One time tested street portrait tactic is to flush your subjects into small alleyways where they have little chance of escape.
He kinda looks like he's showing off something he just lassoed.

"Hold on.  I have one more move to try."
"Oh don't worry -- I'm not going anywhere."

Sometimes on a dark, cold day, you find a bright ray of golden sunshine.
And she gives you Chinese candy.
"You better not get me hit."
"I got kicked out of my house cause their lawyer was bigger than my lawyer.  Cause I don't got one."
CAPTION CONTEST: We haven't had a caption contest in awhile.  Submit your best caption.  "Like" your favorite.  The caption with the most "likes" will go on the main site tomorrow.
I love when people bring their own personal flare to a well-trod fashion statement.

"Fur coat in the winter
Look like a polar bear
Stuntin' in the snow
These haters, they can go somewhere"

I was trying to think of a caption, but just kept thinking:
"This dude fucking rocks."
This portrait has a Wes Anderson feel to it.
Yesterday Ty Pennington became the first celebrity that I've been able to convince I wasn't from TMZ.

Andy Warhol back from the dead.  
This time a bit taller and a little more Asian.

Marx : Socialism
Darwin : Evolution
This Guy: Occupy Wall Street
You never know when Mayhem will strike.

"I don't know."
"C'mon.  I know my Facebook Group. They're going to love you."
"I don't know."
"They're going to love you."
Can you tell we're near the dog park?
This guy gets paid by an Italian restaurant to sit out in front and look Italian.
Doesn't she make a pretty scene?

When it's freezing cold and you're searching for street portraits, 
it sure will warm your soul to see this guy on the opposite sidewalk.

"Yo Man!  Take my photo."
"Ok, but you have to tell me something interesting about yourself."
"Like what?"
"Anything."
"I don't know man.  I'm just a normal guy.  I play guitar, but I broke it over the telephone booth last week after my friend died of an overdose on Spring Street."
"That'll work."
Not sure how much more you could ask for in a street portrait.

Somebody commented that there's been a lack of cute kids lately.
So I'm bringing them back with a vengeance.

"But we're from London."
"Not today."

I'm from Brazil, but I was in NYC in Feb/Mar 2011 and you took a picture of me. I was passing through a severe case of depression, having suicidal thoughts because it was my dream to visit NYC but everything was going wrong. I was even homeless for three days when you saw me in that park. I don't remember where it was, but I guess it was near Brooklyn? I don't know, I was such a mess back then. I was starving, cold and simply wanting to die.

I'm back in Brazil, went to a psychiatrist, took medications, got over the depression and I'm feeling awesome. Better as I have never felt before. Then I found your card in my stuff and I could barely remember what it was, but when I entered the website, I found my photo. It's attached to this email since I can't find it anymore.

My face says it all: depression. I look at the picture and I remember how awful it was, then I get happy I got over that. Your picture makes me smile everytime I see it because of that. So I just wanted to thank you.

-John

I waiting for the subway at the Classon Ave stop when I noticed that someone had written on an advertisement for MOMA's Diego Rivera exhibit.  It was such nice penmanship that I pulled out my camera.  Only then did I notice a small figurine on the ledge, which I have magnified.  Altogether it was quite a poetic scene.

"So what's the shirt?"
"It's called Kill-again's Island.  It's a satire about the thing I hate most."
"What's that?"
"Smokers."
"Oh did you used to smoke?"
"No, but I've had two nervous breakdowns caused by smokers."
"Oh man.  What happened?"
"Well the second breakdown was caused by someone mentioning the first breakdown.  Now whenever I see a smoker I feel very violent.  But I'm on medication."
"Well, it was nice meeting you. Gotta go!"
One size fits all.

"What are you doing in New York?"
"[Inaudible]... temple... [inaudible]... ceremony."

Humans of New York Nature Crime Report:
At approximately 2:15 PM, a hawk brought down a full-grown pigeon in the skies above 175th Street.  The takedown was witnessed by two excited bystanders, also pictured.  When approached by a local photoblogger, the hawk fled the scene.  In an effort to revive the conflict, one bystander threw the wounded pigeon in the direction of the hawk.  Aided by the launch, the wounded pigeon managed to escape.

HONY has been around for about a year and a half.  But 10,000 of the page’s fans have joined within the last month.   With over 100 comments for some photos, being featured on HONY has become a potentially intimidating experience.  For those of you who are new: the purpose of this blog is to celebrate individuality.  This is not the place to make fun of people, or to give your honest opinion  --- if your honest opinion happens to be hurtful.   Mean comments will be immediately deleted.  I don’t mean to silence anyone.  But this group is about to get very big, and it’s never going to work unless we protect the people who make it special.  You are a great group of people, and I’m so thankful for all of you.  Brandon.

I was about to put up a photo, but then this letter popped up in my inbox.  Written by a 15 year old.  (Can you believe it?)  
I'm sharing this because she really describes my personal view of HONY.  If HONY leans too far toward the "softer" side of New York, it's because I think so many other people/artists lean too far toward the "harder," "edgier" side.  

==================================

Dear HONY,

Recently life has been kind of sucky, for lack of a more eloquent term to describe the terribly saddening effects that new york cynicism has on a person. don't get me wrong, i think cynics are just as beautiful as everyone else -- hell, i am one, & proud of it -- but sometimes i need reminding that there is a prettier side to the world.

because some mornings on toolong commutes to a brick prison for somewhat psychotic (read: "academically gifted") high school students, the only things that get through to you are the beggars & homeless people curled up on seats; coming back from poetry slams & jazz clubs at night the high from letting go of all your inhibitions for an evening is crushed by the drug addicts & a woman whose face is caked with too much makeup & the apathetic look of someone who gave up on life far too young & far too quickly. when you get out of the subway station you realize that there are too many skyscrapers & not enough sky, & wonder how such a dreary existence of a city could get to be so idealized -- the reality of new york doesn't always match up with the postcards, does it?
 
usually, i've always been able to find beauty in the strangest things: poetry lying in the train tracks, boys reading russian novels on the E train, that fountain on the corner of 53rd and lex that looks like it's trickling liquid hope. you can always find the sparkle in something if you try hard enough, but i suppose the whole being a teenage girl thing had dragged me down too much for trying to be worth it. & i guess as of late there has also just been a lack of lovely, in general -- i realize it's spring, & all, but i dunno. perhaps large amounts of lovely have migrated to, i don't know, canada. (i would be more than willing to lend some to syria, or maybe uganda; goodness knows they need it.) but then a few weeks ago i found your blog & remembered how gorgeous life & the city that never [stops trying to get laid],  sleeps can be.

i love the portraits. i love the captions. i've started checking your page every morning the way i drink my morning cup of coffee -- i think that if i went without it, i might just crash trying to get myself through the day. you wouldn't believe the amount of poetry i've written using your photos as inspiration, & i've even got the beginnings of a song coming along right now, about that picture of two guys kissing at the occupy rally the other day. your page makes me feel not alone; it's amazing how easy it is to feel secluded while surrounded by eight million (or is it nine?) other faces each day, but i've realized that our uniqueness is precisely what brings & holds everyone together.

i just thought you should know that you reminded me how addicted i am to beauty when times aren't so great (yay teenage angst!). thank you.

I was just eating alone at a diner.  In the booth next to me there was an old man and his wife, who seemed to have really bad Alzheimer's.  The man was so gentle and sweet with her.  At one point she asked: "Can we watch a movie later?"  He replied: "We can watch half of one-- we started one before we came."  Then later she asked him his name, and he pronounced it in different languages until she remembered.

The Approach:

First of all, accept that some people will say “no.” A few people may even act offended that you asked.  This has nothing to do with you, or what you are doing.  Do not let these people make you feel rude.  Do not let these people make you feel weird.  There is nothing wrong with politely asking another person for their photograph.  Most people will be honored.  

Accept that you are going to be nervous when you first begin stopping people.  This is completely natural.  You must keep asking until you are no longer nervous.  This takes time.  But it’s the most important step.  It doesn’t really matter how you ask.  The most important part of asking is to remain completely calm.  And you must earn this comfort.

Remember that people tend to reflect each other’s emotions-- so if you are nervous, your subjects will be nervous.  When you are calm, your subjects will be calm.  And they will allow you to take their photo.  

Normally, the only thing I say is: 
“Is there any way I can take your photograph?”  
If they hesitate, I’ll add: “You look great.”

Ask everyone.  Your best portraits will be the people you were most afraid to ask.  

Speak softly.  
Smile. 
Never approach from the rear.  
Carry a business card—it will put people at ease.  

If you are photographing a child, always ask the parent first.  I don’t even interact with a child before speaking to the parent.  

If a person wants to know why you are asking— just be honest.  I often say: “You have a great face.”  Or “Your hat matches the color of the stop sign.”

I’ll end where I began— you must accept that some people will say “no.”  Rejection is the hardest part of the process.  A few people will try to make you feel weird for asking, and it can wear you down.  Don’t let it.  It is not weird to politely ask a stranger for their photograph.  It is a respectful and beautiful thing.  

COMING SOON: The Process

Everything I've Learned About Street Portraits:

I wrote this to help people with their own Humans projects.  This is just my way of doing things-- it is by no means a rulebook.  

I will promote your Humans project as long as it follows the “spirit” of HONY.  This means street portraits, not documentary photography.  It means interacting with strangers—actually entering their lives for a few moments, and telling their story with images and words. 

As long as you do that-- and show a couple weeks of dedication, I’ll share your work with the HONY audience.  

------------------------

The Approach:

First of all, accept that some people will say “no.” A few people may even act offended that you asked.  This has nothing to do with you, or what you are doing.  Do not let these people make you feel rude.  Do not let these people make you feel weird.  There is nothing wrong with politely asking another person for their photograph.  Most people will be honored.  

Accept that you are going to be nervous when you first begin stopping people.  This is completely natural.  You must keep asking until you are no longer nervous.  This takes time.  But it’s the most important step. 

Because the most important part of asking for a stranger’s portrait is remaining completely calm.  People tend to reflect each other’s emotions-- so if you are nervous, your subject will be nervous.  Normally, the only thing I say is “Do you mind if I take your photo?”  A lot of times, I don’t even explain the blog until after the photo has been taken.

Speak softly.  Smile.  Never approach from the rear.  (People almost always say no if you tap them on the shoulder)  Carry a business card.  

-----------------------

The Process

Once someone has agreed to be photographed, they will probably have no problem helping you take the best possible portrait.  If they are in a hurry—snap it where they stand-- you got what you could.  But if they have a few moments, try to control as many variables as possible.

Look around.  Where is the light best?  Where’s the best backdrop?  Whenever I spot a person that I’d like to photograph, I’m immediately scanning my surroundings.  By the time I finally approach them—I almost always have an “idea” to suggest.  It normally involves walking a little bit, but people are almost always willing to go the “extra mile.”   If they’ve already agreed, why wouldn’t they want to help you take the best possible portrait?   

As you can probably tell from my portraits—in the absence of a better surrounding, I almost always prefer the middle of the street. 

Be playful and have fun.  If you act stiff and over-professional, you are going to get a stiff looking portrait.  I’ve seen street photographers setting up portraits as if they are in a studio—asking their subjects to tilt their head “just-so” or arch their back “just so.”  The final result is a “technically perfect” photo featuring a very unnatural, apprehensive looking subject.  Remember, a portrait is intended to express your subject—not your photography skills.  

Street photography is unpredictable.  Your subjects will do unexpected things.  Let these things happen.   Don’t try to “control” every part of the photo.  If a subject has an “idea” for a pose, I always jump on board.  Let go.  Some of my favorite portraits have come from the unexpected.  Let chaos work for you.

*One rule I always follow--- drop to one knee when photographing children. 
Get on their level. *

Headshots have their own power, but I prefer full body shots because they bring more of the person, as well as the city, into the photo.  Sometimes a person has a great face or haircut that will call for a close-up.  Otherwise, I prefer to feature as much of the person as possible.   Taking full-body shots also brings a lot of The City into my portrait.  When documenting the people of a city, I think context matters.    

Finally--- talk to the person, but be natural.  Don’t act like Mike Wallace on 60 Minutes.  Act like a human.  Take a quick interest.  Joke with them.   Adding even the simplest quote to a photo can lend so much humanity to an image.   If conversation doesn’t come naturally, try asking a quick question.    

Good Luck!

Why do so many people think that the price of a meal buys them the right to be a tyrant toward a waiter?  I think the best way to judge a person's character is to observe how they treat people from which they have nothing to gain.
So a few weeks ago somebody started a Poops of New York Tumblr.  I thought: "For sure, he will quit after a few days."  This man has photographed a piece of poop everyday for the last month:

Hey everyone,

Humans of New York is in danger of losing its way.  For the longest time it was a very positive place.  But lately it has  begun to show symptoms of one of humanity's worst diseases: the tendency to make sweeping judgments about people based on very small amounts of information.  

Put simply: the comment section is out of control.

I've been so excited about the site's growth.  And I'm so happy that such a large community has developed.  Ecstatic, actually.  But at its core-- HONY remains a blog of my photography.  And I have a very important responsibility to the people I photograph.  

Unfortunately, the "right to free speech" does not apply here.  This is not the place to further an ideology at the expense of an individual.  Despite how it may seem-- we do not know the people in these portraits.  We are in no position to judge them.  Anyone doing so will be banned.  Banned users will still be able to look the photos, but they will be unable to comment.

I have never banned someone for criticizing me.  And you may continue to do so.  But the subjects of these photos are now off limits.  Good-natured ribbing will still be allowed.  Mean-spirited slander will not be.  

This may curb some of the interesting discussions we've been having.  But we cannot continue to have these discussions at the expense of an individual.  It is unethical.  Better to put the brakes on the site's growth then to destroy the energy upon which it was founded.

I know I've made mistakes too.  I'm going to try to be even more careful moving forward.  But let's try to get back to saying nice things about strangers.  In short, let's make HONY different than the rest of the internet.

Thanks so much for your support,
Brandon

When you're feeling down, it's so tempting to focus on your sadness: you wonder why you're sad, you hate that you're sad, you wish you weren't sad.  It's completely natural to do this. But it's the wrong way to be.  No matter how smart you are-- you will never change a bad mood by thinking about it.  You will only magnify it.

Instead focus on your behavior.  Focus on what you can change.  Go outside.  Exercise.  Quit isolating yourself.  Interact with friends and family.  Accomplish things.  Your mind will reward you with happiness.

It is so tough to change your behavior if you are feeling depressed.  But it's the only way.  Don't say: "I'll act differently when I feel better."  

Act differently, and you will feel better.

"He was my first love.  We dated for ten days when we were very young, but my mom would not allow the relationship.  She told me: 'He's an American, and he's an actor.  He'll never make anything of himself.'  Then she told me: 'There are millions of men, but I'm your only mother.'  She told me to never contact him again, and I listened to her.

She took me to Korea for awhile, and when I came back, I never made contact with him again.  I never even gave him an explanation.  That was over twenty years ago.  

Then four years ago I Googled him.  I saw that he was running a theater company.  I wrote him a long letter out of the blue, explaining everything.  We'd both been married.  We both had kids.  But here we are-- finally together."

Late last night I saw a man crossing 3rd Avenue, weighed down by two armloads of groceries.  He didn't seem to notice that cars were coming in both directions.  They began honking at him.  Some slammed on their brakes.  I waited for the man to realize his mistake and turn around, but instead he just plowed forward across four busy lanes of traffic.  It did not seem like he was making any mental calculations-- it was just full speed ahead.  

When he finally emerged on the other side, I approached him.  "I'm just curious," I said.  "Did you see those cars coming, and decide to go anyway?  Or did you just suddenly find yourself in the middle of the situation?"

"It was an accident," he said.  "I just found myself in some shit and had to keep going.  Which, incidentally, is pretty much how I've lived my entire life."
The guy said he was working at Jamba Juice while going to school.  The girl said she was "a mermaid, most of the time."

I went to the Post Office yesterday with a second batch of HONY prints, sizably larger than the first batch I'd sent the day before.  The place was full of customers, but there were only two windows open.  I tried not to make eye contact with any of the despondent customers behind me.  There was an employee helping to direct the line.  She looked at my box of envelopes and said: “This very difficult.  You make big, big trouble.”

When I finally got to an open window, the employee immediately looked at my box of envelopes and said: “I’ll be right back, I need a cigarette.”  

When she came back, an argument immediately broke out between her and a fellow employee about what to do with me.  The problem centered around the fact that all my envelopes were different weights, and therefore could not be run as a single batch.  The lady at my window-- let’s call her Tanya-- seemed to think she needed to weigh them one at a time.  The other employee was in favor of selling me a giant pile of stamps, and letting me figure it out.

Tanya stuck to her guns, and started putting the envelopes on the postal scale.  She started playing Justin Beiber’s “Baby” on her Iphone.  “This is my granddaughter’s favorite song,” she told me.  She started singing along and dancing in her seat.  

The other employee shot Tanya an angry look, left the room, and returned with the manager.  When Tanya noticed this, she began shaking her head theatrically, and exclaimed: “How’s she gonna get the manager?  There are too many Snoop Dogs in this place.”  Then Tanya turned to the manager and said:  “This isn’t a band.  Nobody asked you to orchestrate.”

“I’m telling you to sell him stamps,” he replied.
“Nobody tells me what to do," said Tanya, "I’ve worked here 29 years.  You can suggest whatever you want, but nobody tells me what to do.”
“I DO tell you what to do.”
“Write me up.  I’ll help you proofread it.”  Then Tanya looked at me, “He thinks I’m afraid of a piece of paper.”
“You’re not acting like a Christian,” he said.  “I thought you were a Christian.”
“I am a Christian,” Tanya replied.  “A gangsta Christian.  Bronx-born and raised.”

The yelling continued for about 30 minutes.  Tanya kept trying to bring me into the argument, saying things like “Ain’t that right?”  I just laughed nervously.  In the end, I left with a giant pile of stamps.

"What do you want me to do?"
"You don't have to do anything.  I'm  going to lay on the ground."

"What color are my eyes?"
"Brown.  With a little bit of blue."
"Are you crazy?"
"I don't think so."
"They are gray THEN blue THEN brown."
"Oh."
Not sure what happened here, but it looks like it was tiring.

I was walking with my roommate down Classon Ave when we started to come upon a cluster of housing projects.  Suddenly there was a rapid series of loud "pops" coming from about about 50 yards in front of us: *POP* *POP* *POP* *POP* *POP.*  The "pops" were loud, but not that loud.  I saw a group of kids scurrying inside a doorway.  I thought that maybe they'd set off some fireworks.  

"What was that?" I asked my roommate.
"Fireworks," he said.
"Are you sure?"
"Yeah man, fireworks."
"Maybe we should go another way."
"Nah man, they were fireworks."

I saw residents peeking out of windows.  Some came down to the street and timidly looked around.  From the looks on their faces, they didn't seem to think they'd heard fireworks.  

Suddenly a man in a suit walked up to us, he had buzzed hair and a pair of handcuffs dangling from his belt.  "Where'd the shots come from?" he asked.  We pointed in front of us.  We followed the cop for a few yards when a group of kids came running across the street.  "There's a bullet in my butt," shouted one of the girls, "I got shot in the butt!"

I'd always heard that gunshots sound like fireworks.
Very much so.

It's almost as difficult to get portraits in mid-July as it is in mid-January.  It's been so hot and muggy these last few days, everyone feels like they're walking underwater.  So nobody is too anxious to stop and talk to strangers.  Seems like every word is a strain.  Take the conversation I had with this man, for example:

"May I take your photo?"
"Whaaaaat?"
"May I take your photo?"
"Whhhhhy?"
"I run a popular website, I take pictures of people."
"Juh-Juh-Juh-Just do it.  Are you done?"
"I'm done."
"Bye."
This man is from Haiti.  I've actually seen him twice.  But the first time I couldn't photograph him, because he was doing some deep, standing, palms-up meditation next to a Union Square drum circle.
"Some girl just asked me if I sold drugs.  So I asked her if she sold slaves."

"It's French for 'army of shadows.'"
"And what does that mean to you?"
"I was going through a really rough time in my life, and it felt like a whole army was after me.  But when I started feeling better, I realized it was nothing but an army of shadows."
It's tough to pull off that shirt without a good pair of jean shorts.
I saw this guy from several blocks away because he is nearly seven feet tall.  As he passed, I asked him how we was doing.  "I'm present," he said.  Then he showed me how to meditate like the ocean.

"I thought about getting a dog.  But I didn't want to walk it or clean up poop, so I got this instead."
"What is it exactly?  Is that a toy?  Or is it art?"
"It's art."

These two were the closest thing to a real-life Beavis and Butthead that I've ever seen.  They walked up out of nowhere and just started flicking my nipples and saying: "Bean dip!  Bean dip! Bean dip!"  Then they started snickering.  

I started laughing at the absurdity of the situation.  Encouraged by my laughter, they tried to wedge their hands into my armpits while shouting: "Salmon!  Salmon!  Salmon!"  This was accompanied by more snickering.

"I'm waiting for my psychologist appointment."
"Can I write that in the caption?"
"I've been in therapy for 30 years.  It's not exactly a secret."

"What's the story here?"
"Just having fun."

"It's S.M.A.S.H today!"
"What does that mean?"
"Super Monthly Awesome Spectacular Halloween.  It's like Halloween, but once a month!"
"Oh, is this a sort of group thing?"
"It was supposed to be, but nobody wanted to do it with us."

"More often than not, the sons of successful merchants are extremely nervous and insecure.  It's a phenomenon I saw a lot growing up in Miami Beach.  The men who built Miami Beach grew up in the ghettos of the Northeast.  They were very motivated and hard-driving, and determined to provide their children with all the luxuries they never had.  They didn't realize that providing a child with everything is the quickest way to destroy his confidence in his own abilities.  I saw it time and time again.  Rich merchants.  Insecure children."

"I'm an abstract artist."
"Where do you draw your inspiration from?"
"I'm very interested in prisons, which I think is reflected in my work.  I've done a lot of research on prisons, and have even been able to visit a few."
"What was the most interesting thing you learned in your research?"
"The fact that many prisons are privatized now-- they're run by corporations and traded on the stock exchange.  It can almost be seen as modern day slavery.  When the stock market crashed a few years ago, prison stocks did surprisingly well."

"You should never say: 'I'm poor.'  Instead you should always say: 'I live in abundance.'  Give it a try.  I did it for a whole month once.  People were buying me lunches, theater tickets-- it was great."

This man really made me smile.  Immediately after I asked for his photo, it became apparent that he didn't speak English.  This is normally a deal breaker.  It is very difficult to convince a stranger to let you take their photo if they cannot understand a word you are saying.

But I attempted my usual sign language, which involves pointing at the camera then pointing at the person's face.  (All while smiling stupidly.)  And this time it worked.  The man straightened his shoulders, stared into the lens of the camera, and smiled.  I took his portrait and thanked him profusely.

I began to walk away when I heard him calling to me.  I turned around and saw him tugging at his traditional clothing.  "Me Pakistan!" he said.  "Me Pakistan!"

When I first spotted this girl she was crossing the road with her mother, hand-in-hand.  Her mother was wearing a bright blue sari.  They made quite a pair.

But when I asked them for a photo, the mother demurred.  She didn't seem distrusting, just shy.  She pursed her lips into a smile and started shaking her head slowly.  Meanwhile the daughter was nodding her head frantically.  She tried to encourage her mother by tugging on her arm.  The mother laughed and said: "Not me, but you can take a picture of her."  

The girl immediately assumed a self-satisfied pose.

No difference / Shel Silverstein

Small as a peanut 
Big as a giant, 
We're all the same size 
When we turn off the light. 
Red black or orange, 
Yellow or white 
We all look the same 
When we turn off the light. 
So maybe the way 
To make everything right 
Is for God to just reach out 
And turn off the light!

"Everyone who sees my resume asks me why I drive a cab.  Back in Niger, I was a French teacher.  But the government stopped paying us for a few months, so I decided to quit my job and move to America.  That was 12 years ago. 

I thought I could teach French here, but I had no idea how hard it would be to get a job without papers.  The only place I could find work was a carwash.  Back in Niger, kids would wash my car for me.  Now all day long I was washing cars for other people.  I was very depressed.  But I was too embarrassed to go back home.  Then one year after I arrived, George Bush got elected and everyone was telling me that it meant very bad things for me.  They said the Republicans would make trouble for me.  So I was very scared.   

After the car wash, I became a stock boy.  Then, a delivery driver.  Five years ago, I got my papers and became a citizen, so now I'm able to work at the airport.  At nights, and on my days off, I drive a cab.  Just this year I graduated from Brooklyn College with a Masters degree in French.  I finished third in my class.  Now I think I can become a professor."
Testing Boundaries

First, I read this in the NY Times this morning:

"By the next morning, the scene was considerably calmer, even anemic. At 9 a.m., the only sign of life was at Reynard, where the tables were filled by couples in their 40s and older. They were out-of-town parents — giveaways with their cargo shorts."

Then, I looked down:

This man was from Israel and had a very thick accent, so he was a little difficult to understand.  He was standing alone when I found him, but he kept telling me he wanted to take a picture  with "his bike."  

I couldn't see a bike anywhere, so I kept asking him to repeat himself.  "My bike," he said, "my bike."  

Just when I was about to give up, his bike walked up.

I found this man standing near a fruit stand on the corner of 14th St and 7th Avenue.  I assumed he was waiting for someone.  I thought he looked awesome so I asked him for a photograph.  He agreed, so I took a few quick shots and continued walking down the sidewalk.   

As I walked away, I scrolled through the photographs, and decided that they weren't so great.  So I went back for another try.  When I found the man again, he was stacking fruit.  Turns out he owned the fruit stand, making him the best-dressed fruit vendor in the city.

He explained that he was from Turkey, was studying International Business at Baruch College, and sold fruit to cover his expenses.
Unbeknownst to billions of mortals around the world, the final battle for the Universe was going down last night in Washington Square Park.

John Lloyd Young won a Tony and a Grammy for his portrayal of Frankie Valli in Jersey Boys.  He's back in town for three months, guest starring in his old role.  After seeing the show last week, I fired off an email hoping to get a photograph.  He's doing eight shows a week, but agreed to meet me this afternoon before he went into the August Wilson theater.

John spent the few minutes we had together talking about HONY, which really caught me off guard.  I wasn't sure he'd even had the chance to look at the blog, and here he is expressing a very detailed appreciation.  He barely left me time to tell him how much I loved his performance.

Anyway, John Lloyd Young: Tony winner, Grammy winner,  really nice dude.  If you haven't seen him in Jersey Boys-- you're really missing out.

A couple weeks ago, I posted this photo with this caption:

"He barely spoke any English. But I did gather that he'd recently moved from Cuba, and had come to America for "La Libertad."

After seeing the post, the man sought the services of a translator in order to fully express his story.  Here is the version that showed up my inbox today:

"This is my story and it’s real. I was born in the humble town of Central Guatemala on the Island of Cuba after Castro's revolutionary triumph. I have been living in exile in the USA for the past 3 years. I come from a very beautiful and united family. I miss and love my family immensely. I never stop thinking about them, not even for an instant. Despite living here in America I still worry about their well-being and day-to-day necessities.

My mother, who is the most precious person in my world, is battling cancer.  Not being able to see her face-to-face and tell her how much I love her deeply hurts me. Due to Castro's cruel dictatorship, however, living in America means that my entry into Cuba is not permitted. As such, it’s not possible for me to see my mother, to hug her, and to tell her how much I miss her. I am afraid that I may never see my mother again.

Being a professional sportsman gave me the opportunity to represent Cuba in a workshop in Venezuela named ‘Barrio Adentro Deportivo’, which is one of the methods used by the Cuban regime to portray Castro's dictatorship as benevolent. Many of us are ‘selected’ to go abroad using coercion, deceit and threats. If you refuse to go, the regime degrades your economic and social status. Some Cubans opt to follow this charade and use it as a means to improve their social and financial status. Others, like me, decide to use it as a gateway and potential escape to a better life.

Migrating to a new country has been a very difficult experience, as it has been for many other Cubans who, like me, made the decision to leave Cuba to be embraced by this and other nations. These adopting countries have given many of us their support and solidarity because they are aware of the suffering we have experienced in leaving behind our families, friends, culture and, often, our hearts. Many of us have risked our lives fleeing through the borders of several nations in search of liberty. It is shameful and painful, but nevertheless true, that many Cubans have to face such calamities in order to achieve a right that The Creator has given to all humanity: the right to freedom."
Seen in Flushing, Queens.
He sent me a follow-up email to clarify that the haircut is known as a "cheerio bowl."
"I'm a choreographer, so images are very important to me."

I stumbled upon a National Treasure yesterday.

I was walking down 3rd Avenue when I noticed an old man in a wheelchair.  He was being pushed by a caretaker.  Despite his physical condition, he had dressed with extreme care.  He wore an outlandish yellow outfit.  Everything about him was yellow, from his shades to his socks.  Intrigued by his appearance, I bent down and asked for a photograph.  He silently nodded approval.

After I'd taken his photograph, his caretaker offered a formal introduction: "This is Banana George," she said, "the world's oldest barefoot waterskier.  He's 97 now.  When he was 92, he set the world record for the oldest person to waterski barefoot."  

Banana George didn't even begin waterskiing until he was 40.  But it soon became his passion.  So much so that he began doing shows at Cypress Gardens-- hopping jumps and riding with women on his shoulders.  In the course of his career, he's broken his back 4 times.  He's also broken his ankle, knee, and eleven ribs.  Banana George waterskied until the last possible moment.  I've seen footage of a very old George being pulled through the water in a wheelchair-on-skis, smiling like a madman.

Here you can see a short video I found of Banana George skiing on his 90th birthday:  http://bit.ly/ri0bD3

Banana George is a testament to loving life, and he deserves to be celebrated.  I discovered that his family set up a fan page for him.  It only has 835 people so far.  Let's show George how much we love his spirit, and join his fan group: http://on.fb.me/P0f087

If you think Banana George deserves to be known, please SHARE this story.  And in the words of Banana George: "Don't wait for the next thing, make the next thing happen!"

This all happened within a 5 minute period, on the same Brooklyn-bound subway car:

I noticed a man with an elaborate gold ring, and questioned him about it's origin.  "It's from Ghana," he said.  
"Cool!" I replied. "Do you have any idea how old it is?"
"About 200 years," he answered.  Excited by this discovery, I asked him if I could photograph the ring.  That picture can be found in the top left corner of this post.  

The man got off at the next stop.  Shortly after he left the car, I recognized another man who I had met a few weeks earlier.  I knew that he collected and dealt in African artwork.     I walked up to him with the intention of showing off my discovery.  "Check out this ring," I said, showing him the photo on my camera.  "The guy said it was 200 years old and made in Ghana."  He quickly glanced at the photo.

"Bah!" he said.  "That's way too shiny to be 200 years old.  You want to see something old?"  He opened his briefcase, reached into one of the pockets, and pulled out a bundle of tissue.  He unwrapped the tissue, revealing a sort of artifact.  "That was dug up in Mali," he said.  "Photograph that!"
Chaotic, yet very carefully pieced together.

"I've won a few acting awards, but as with all art, it's an endless journey."
"What do you mean?"
"You never get to the bottom of an art.  There's always another layer of depth.  Whether that be painting, or acting, or photography.  Ten different people could photograph that tree right there, and there would be ten different spirits beneath those photographs."
"I think I'll put that as your caption."
"Oh c'mon.  That's nothing new.  Everyone knows that."
"Maybe so. But ten different people could explain that ten different ways."

"My father has Asperger's, so it's always been very difficult to connect with him emotionally.  Then a few years ago I was reading Truman Capote's 'Other Voices, Other Rooms,' and there's this scene where the main character prays to know his father.  And when he's done praying, the chapter ends: 'And in this moment, like a swift intake of breath, the rain came.'"

Dear HONY,

I want to nominate my Uncle Naldo for a portrait.  His father left when he was four and he became the man of the house. A Vietnam combat veteran, he worked in warehouses and trucking until he got laid off in the late nineties. After a few years of job-searching and clinical depression, he found peace, purpose, and community working as a doorman on the Upper West Side. He buys bags of dog biscuits for the dozens of dogs from the neighborhood who jerk their walkers to his post, then sit anxiously for a treat. 

You can find him at 41 west 72nd st, where he works Thursday to Monday, from 4 to Midnight.

Thomas Colon

"My brother and I moved to New York when I was 12 years old.  We'd been living with my grandmother in Philadelphia, but she said it was time to go live with my mother.  We didn't want to go.  When we got off the bus, I remember my brother grabbed my hand and said: 'Watch out!  The buildings are going to fall on us!'  We'd never seen such tall buildings.  When he got to my mother's apartment building in Harlem, I was shocked.  Most of the doors were open.  There were bums lying on the floor of the hall.  I remember thinking: 'This can't be where we are going to live!'  I think the happiest moment of my life was when I was finally able to move out of Harlem."

I've had a blog crush on Joanna Goddard for awhile now.  Meaning that I'd always hoped one day she'd notice HONY and mention it on her [extremely popular] blog.  Today she wrote a very nice post on Humans of New York, even going so far as to say that HONY had "stolen her heart."

Two years ago, when I first started HONY, I remember reading some advice from Joanna.  She said: "Talk to your audience like you'd talk to your friends."  I really think that wisdom helped set the tone for HONY.  And it's great advice for anyone trying to get a blog off the ground. 

Joanna is certainly a master of "being herself" and using an authentic voice.  It's one of the reasons that her blog has developed such a massive following.  Be sure to check it out.

"Well, you may have a point there."

I first noticed the older woman.  She was walking down the sidewalk, occasionally stopping to playfully poke someone with her cane. HONY just passed 200,000 followers!  And I've got a great story for you to mark the occasion:

Dear HONY,

I needed a metro card to get to work, but my credit card was not working in any of the machines.  I went into a convenience store and asked if I could purchase anyone's food/drink in exchange for cash, and one man took me up on it.  So I got $2.25.

But when I went down to the machine, I found that I was still a quarter short.  I went into a Starbucks and asked 15 people  if I could buy their coffee.  Nobody answered.  At this point I was getting frantic.  I desperately approached a coffee cart vendor, and explained my situation.

The man smiles and says, "Here, take a dollar."
"Thanks," I told him, "but I only need a quarter. My credit card works everywhere except the subway. But thank you."
"Wait," he told me.  "Since you have no money, take $10. You can pay me back tomorrow, or not at all. It's not a big deal."

This guy gave me $11 even though I've never met the guy, seen him before, or bought even a coffee from the cart... and after I've been searching for 25 cents for almost an hour. 

You can find him right outside the Bowling Green 4/5 stop.  Near the Starbucks.  He works until Noon.

Mark

In nature news-- the residents of 35 Cornelia Street are holding vigil over a baby bird that has fallen from its nest, injuring its right wing.  The amateur medical community at 35 Cornelia remains cautiously optimistic.

"A full recovery is expected,"  reports one resident.  "The wing is being exercised everyday, and the mother comes down from the nest to deliver food.  Should be flying in no time."  

Until the prognosis is fulfilled, the building's Russian Wolfhound, Rhett, is being kept on a short leash.

Despite irresponsible reports from major news outlets, the event at Lincoln Center tonight was not an extraterrestrial welcoming ceremony.  It was the Diner en Blanc-- a self-described 'tres-chic' flashmob feast which began in Paris.  Every year, the feast's location is announced immediately before the event.  With a waiting list of 30,000 people, the event is roped off from the public and very difficult to get into.  Unless you run across the street and buy a $30 white collared shirt from Century 21, and act natural.

"In November of 42, my unit was building airstrips in Scotland when we received an order to pack up our things.  They put us on ships in the middle of the night.  You couldn't see anything, and they didn't tell us where we were going.  When the sun came up, we saw that we were part of a giant convoy.   There were hundreds of ships, all across the horizon: cruisers, destroyers, transport ships.  It looked just like a movie.  Turns out we were headed to Algeria.  When we hit the Straight of Gibraltar, all the ships had to come together, which made us vulnerable to air attacks.  So suddenly the sky was filled with British fighters giving us cover.  Tons of them.  When we landed, we built runways so that the Allies could supply their North African operations.  I was behind the lines because I was an engineer, but the Germans were hitting us pretty hard in North Africa.  I remember all the boys heading toward the front on tanks.  Lines and lines of them.  They knew it was the real thing this time, so their faces looked pretty grim. "

UPDATE:  The couple in the photo were located as a result of the HONY post.  Man on the left is a graffiti artist.  Woman on the right was serving as his lookout.  She describes their relationship as a "whirlwind summertime romance."  The woman is refusing to sign a release form until the man gets out of Rikers.

Photographer Mo Gelder needs the release because he is the front-runner in Canon's Imagin8tion contest with Ron Howard.  If he wins, a short film will be made based on the photograph.  

Currently, Mr. Gelder is fielding several interview requests.  (Understandably.  What a story, and what a photograph!  One of the best candid photos I've ever seen.)  Because of Gelder's photograph, Canon's contest is getting tons of publicity.  (HONY is getting it's fair share as well.  Thanks Mo!)  I've got to imagine that Canon is trying to figure out a way to include Mr. Gelder in their plans, with or without a release!  I'll keep everyone updated on their decision.

Turns out, however, she was telling the truth.  She was indeed charmingly bashful.  She couldn't even bring herself to look at the camera.  And I could hear the keys jingling in her pocket from across the street.

Yesterday I dropped into a pet store called Fauna on the Upper West Side, because it had a sign saying "Exotic Birds" and I thought: "Sweet! Free zoo."  Indeed, it had a small bird habitat with all sorts of awesome birds.

I got into a conversation with Daniel, the store's owner, about the bonding abilities of these animals.  I looked at their small heads, imagined their small brains, and said: "These things probably could care less about humans."

In response, Daniel opened the cage of a nearby parrot.  The parrot instantly darted out, landed on Daniel's shoulder, and started frantically nuzzling against his face.  It was quite a demonstration.  What amazing creatures.
"Ladies not yet rich but very well off will also be considered."

I was walking through Central Park yesterday when I heard a loud, driving, constant drum beat.  It was coming from a distant hill, upon which a small circle of people had gathered around a dancing group of Native Americans.  The dance, I learned, was part of a "sendoff ceremony" for a modern Mayan prophet who'd stopped in New York as part of a speaking tour.

This is the Mayan Holy Man (plus translator) referenced in the previous post.  I think he was speaking all day, so I only caught a portion of his message, but here's what I heard:

"When the Mayans cut down a tree, they pray not only to the guardians of the tree, but to the guardians of the animals that sought shelter in that tree.  Now, more than ever, we need to pray to the guardians of nature.  The Spaniards misunderstood these ceremonies and called us polytheistic.  This was a mistranslation.  But we believe that nature must be guarded.  Sixty years ago my grandmother told me that we would have to pay to drink water.  And now this is coming true.  We are buying water, and we are eating chickens that are so filled with chemicals that they are killed 20 days after they hatch.  These are not natural animals.  Now more than ever, nature must be guarded."
Seen in Central Park
Seen on the Upper East Side

Kapores is an ancient tradition, controversial even within the Orthodox community, of slaughtering a chicken on the eve of Yom Kippur as a symbolic proxy for one's sin. I remember taking an Anthropology class in college, and the professor was explaining that there is little "sexual dimorphism" in humans.  He meant that there are few outward, observable differences between males and females.  (Other than reproductive organs, of course.)

At the time I was confused, so I raised my hand.  "I feel like it's very easy to tell men and women apart," I said.  
"That's due to culture," he explained.

Like everyone, I sometimes feel like I'm in a slump.  I either think I'm not getting enough portraits, or that I'm messing up the portraits I am getting.  This feeling can be magnified by the need for daily content.

Whenever I'm feeling this way, a great portrait will come along that will snap me back to optimism.  And I'll think: "Man, I really needed that."  Tonight that portrait came from Mark, who I just ran into ten minutes ago.  When I finished taking his photo, he said: "Man, my mom is in the hospital, I really needed that."
His mom started to ask him if he wanted his picture taken, but he said "yes" before she could finish.
I think she started to have second thoughts about posing in the street.

"What's your favorite thing about your wife?"
"She's sexy."
"You can try, but she may be too shy..."
